p: In addition to substantive elements, EU approaches to climate justice include a prominent procedural aspect, embracing participation and consultation, transparency and the availability of litigation (as in the landmark Urgenda case, in which the Dutch Supreme Court upheld the finding that the Dutch state was obliged to adhere to a more ambitious mitigation target than that accepted by government: Bouwer 2020; Paiement 2020). The participation of civil society groups has long been important to the crafting of EU climate policy (Derman 2014, 28ff). Stakeholder participation is being further institutionalised through the European Climate Pact (European Commission 2020) and Member State initiatives such as France’s Citizens’ Convention for the Climate. Moreover, as part of the EGD, the Aarhus Regulation may be revised ‘to improve access to administrative and judicial review at EU level for citizens and NGOs’ (European Commission 2019, 23).
